title: 112_s647
content:
The Act is titled the "Montana Mineral Conveyance Act" and includes findings. Congress finds that the Secretary of the Interior conveyed mineral rights in coal tracts near the Northern Cheyenne Indian Reservation to the State of Montana, resulting in substantial public revenues for the State. Despite the economic challenges faced by the Northern Cheyenne tribal community, they do not benefit significantly from these revenues. The Northern Cheyenne Tribe faces economic challenges and lacks revenue sources to address development impacts. In 2002, the Tribe sued the Secretary over the conveyance of Federal coal tracts to the State, citing violations of Federal laws and the trust responsibility to the Tribe. The suit was later withdrawn with prejudice. The Northern Cheyenne Tribe withdrew a lawsuit with prejudice, citing violations of Federal laws and the trust responsibility to the Tribe. The Tribe retains claims against the United States for failing to acquire mineral rights on Reservation land. The Northern Cheyenne Tribe withdrew a lawsuit with prejudice, retaining claims against the United States for failing to acquire mineral rights on Reservation land. If mineral rights conveyances are carried out under this Act, the Tribe will waive all legal claims against the United States related to the loss of mineral rights. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The term "Cheyenne tracts" refers to a 5,000-acre land located in the eastern portion of the State within the boundaries of the Reservation, as depicted on a specific map dated April 7, 2010. The term "Federal tracts" refers to unleased land outside the Reservation boundaries in the State, totaling approximately 5,000 acres and depicted on a specific map. The Reservation consists of approximately 5,000 acres of land located in specific sections within T. 3 S., R. 44 E., T. 3 S., R. 45 E., T. 4 S., R. 44 E., T. 6 N., R. 27 E. The Great Northern Properties refer to the Great Northern Properties Limited. The term "Great Northern Properties" refers to the Great Northern Properties Limited Partnership, a Delaware limited partnership, and any successor to its ownership interest in coal or iron under the Cheyenne tracts. The terms "Reservation," "Secretary," "State," and "Tribe" refer to the Northern Cheyenne Reservation, the Secretary of the Interior, the State of Montana, and the Northern Cheyenne Tribe, respectively. SEC. 4. MINERAL RIGHTS CONVEYANCES.

Great Northern Properties will convey mineral interests to the Tribe, and in return, the Secretary will convey coal rights to Great Northern Properties. The mineral interests conveyed to the Tribe will be immune from State taxation.

SEC. 5. TERMS AND CONDITIONS OF MINERAL CONVEYANCES. (a) Waiver of Legal Claims.--In exchange for mineral conveyances, the Tribe will waive claims related to the United States' failure to acquire private mineral interests on the Reservation. 
(b) Condition.--The Tribe and Great Northern Properties must agree on a revenue-sharing formula for coal produced from Federal tracts before mineral conveyances can be completed. 
(c) Completion of Mineral Conveyances.--After meeting the condition in (b), mineral conveyances under section 4(a) must be completed within 90 days. 
(d) Rescission of Mineral Conveyances.--Provisions for rescinding mineral conveyances are outlined. If a Federal district court invalidates any part of the mineral conveyances under section 4(a) and the judgment is not overturned on appeal, the Secretary or Great Northern Properties can rescind all mineral conveyances. This would result in the Tribe's waiver under subsection (a) being rescinded as well. SEC. 6. ELIGIBILITY FOR OTHER FEDERAL BENEFITS.

No benefits under this Act shall reduce or deny Federal services to the Tribe or its members based on their federally recognized status. 

SEC. 7. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS.

Appropriations necessary to carry out this Act are authorized.
